page.title: 08ORANGE LODGE DAY
page.content: The Irish protestants from Liverpool travel into Southport by train.A procession forms up at the station and they parade toward the sea.There are pipe bands dressed in Highland costume along with a selection of drummers.Each lodge of the Orange order has its own band and very distinctive costume.They carry banners showing William of Orange defeating the Catholics at the battle of the Boyne in 1680.Although it is this battle they are supposed to be celebrating,the true meaning of the day is lost to most of the marchers.When the procession reaches its destination the marchers disperse to enjoy themselves.Many of the adults get drunk and cause a considerable nuisance in the town before departing home to Liverpool at night.
